title: Guided Learning for Role Discovery (GLRD): Framework, Algorithms, and Applications

author: Sean Gilpin, Department of Computer Science, University of California, Davis

segmentation: Hi everyone, I'm Sean gilton.
And I'm going to be talking about our work on adding guidance to the world discovery problem.
And this is work I did with my advisor, Dr Ian Davidson.
And from UC Davis and Tina Eliasi.
Rod from rockers.
And this is a road map of the presentation.
I'm going to give.
You are going to start by talking about what role discovery is.
We're going to talk about the relevant previous work and how our contribution fits into that and what the motivation for our contribution is.
So.
The best way to define role discovery is probably through a personal example.
I'm a graduate student at University.
And so I could be thought of as being part of this University community because I'm likely to interact with other people at the University.
But if you looked within the universities, probably differences in how people interact with each other.
For example, if you look at professors and graduate students, there may be differences in the patterns of how who they interact with and how often they interact with different types of people.
So.
Informally, that's what role discovery is.
We want to find these different groups of people within a role that behave differently in a graph.
So more specifically, the role discovery problem that we're looking at is unsupervised version of Discovery, so we have a graph, but we don't have any knowledge about the types of.
The types of we don't have any prior knowledge of the types of roles that we're looking for, but our contribution to this problem is adding guidance.
So that could also be considered as input to this problem.
The sparsity, diversity and alternative guidance that we add.
And as outputs we want to assign nodes to roles and we also want to figure out what the definition of the different roles are.
So this slide shows the previous work and where our contribution fits into that.
The two most important previous works that are related to our work our this KDD paper in 2011 that introduced an algorithm called RFX.
And that algorithm can take a graph and extract recursive structural features from the graph so that you end up with features for each node that describe.
The structure of the node within the graph.
And in 2012 there was a paper in KDD that described it Rolex algorithm that showed how these types of features could be used in conjunction with non negative matrix factorization's.
To do unsupervised role discovery.
And then a little bit.
I'll talk more about what that non negative matrix formulas non negative matrix formulas azatian is.
But our contribution to this is we add guidance to that NMF formulation.
And.

The reason you would want guidance is because oftentimes people have some idea or some knowledge that they want in part on their data mining algorithm, but they don't have enough knowledge to switch to.
A supervised formulation.
Of, for example, role discovery.
So one way to deal with that when you're when you're in an unsupervised area is to just add that knowledge or that guidance as constraints.
So that's what that's what we do.
That's what our contribution is to this in this work.
So now I'm going to talk about what the non negative matrix factorization formulation of discovery is.
And how we added guidance?
So this slide shows with the non negative matrix factorization.
Version of how the non negative matrix factorization version of Rule Discovery Works.
You start with this feature matrix which has one row for each role in one column for each feature that was extracted from the graph.
And you end up doing and you end up decomposing that into two non negative matrices G&F which are respectively.
The role assignment matrix and the role definition matrix.
So when you look at the.
When you look at the role.
Assignment matrix when you look at each column of those that specifies which nodes belong to.
The roll that's associated with that column.
So there be one column per.
Roll.
So all the every non zero entry and one of these columns will correspond to a node that's assigned to that rule.
And when you look at the role definition.
Matrix, you look at the rows, so there will be.
For each role, there will be one row.
In this role definition matrix and non zero values in the row will correspond to features that are helping to define that role.
Now, here's an overview of the guidance that we add.
And as I mentioned earlier, we add the guidance as constraints.
So we add sparsity diversity in alternative nysca alternative guidance.
But we apply, we apply these as constraints to either the role assignment matrix.
Or the role definition matrix in this table shows why you would want to do that and what effect it would have.
Um?
But I'll just quickly go over what the different types of of guidance are.
Sparsity is.
The usual definition of sparsity, and it can simplify or make role definitions more easy to interpret, possibly.
The diversity constraints seeks to make role definitions or role assignments that are very different from each other.
So we'll talk more about that in the next one of the next slides.
And the alternative, this kindness can be thought of as negative guidance.
And for this constraint.
We we as input provide a known ground or we provide a known role assignment or rule definition.
And we're asking the algorithm to find something that's very different from what we provide, something that's alternative to it.
So here's our formulation for sparsity.
At the top.
All we have is a non negative matrix factorization problem and that's going to be the same for all of the guidance we add and at the bottom we add additional constraints which encode the guidance.
So the constraints we added here are constraints on the L1 norm of either the role assignments or the role definitions, so those are there.
And that will cause there to be more zeros in the rule definition of role assignments.
And therefore things can be easier to interpret.
So in order to discuss this diversity guidance, I've included this figure on the right hand side.
Um?
This shows how the diversity constraint affected a role.
That role definition matrix.
So this diversity guidance has a parameter which allows you to specify how diverse.
Roll definition should be, so I have 3.
I have three role definition matrices stacked vertically here.
In the bottom row definition matrix is the most diverse.
And in this matrix, the black values are zero and the white values or the lighter values are.
Entries with value.
So in the.
In the most diverse case at the bottom.
None of the features are shared across any of the.
Any of their roles, so each role is explained using a completely different set of features and that can make it easier to compare the features because they're defined completely differently.
So for the alternative role Discovery I mentioned before, you have to you have to provide a ground truth role assignment.
Or role definition and in this.
In this formulation there provided here is 2 star or F star.
So.
What what this algorithm will then do is find role definitions or role assignments that are very different than those.
And the way it tries to do that is by.
By using this constraint on, what's a relaxation of angular distance?
So it tries to find a set of role definitions, for example, that's very angularly different.
Then the one that was provided.
Um?
So now I'd like to talk about some of the experiments we did which.
I found it interesting.
The first experiment we did, we were trying to.
We wanted to figure out quantitatively if we could compare these things quantitatively to see if guidance can improve the results of roll discovery.
Or role definitions.
But ground truth world definitions are a little bit hard to come by, So what we did was compare our.
Role definitions using different methods and directly by using them in this identity resolution problem.
And identity resolution problem.
Is pretty simple.
You just for example have two graphs and the graphs that we use.
Our conference Co.
Author graphs where the nodes are authors.
And.
In both graphs you have nodes that are the same people, for example, but you don't know what you don't know their identities, but you want to map.
You want to figure out which nodes are the same in the different graphs.
So the idea that we used in this experiment is that people are in similar graphs might be playing the same rules.
And so we might be able to use rules to match them in these different graphs.
So here are the results we have.
In this leftmost figure, there's five groups of.
Of conferences, there's CI Cam and the far left.
And then it's SDMS.
I CDM, SIGMOD and VLDB.
So KDD was matched with each of these conferences.
There coauthor graphs?
And free to the conferences we used for techniques to compare.
We used.
We use the raw structural features, then we use UN guided role discovery and we use is sparse role discovery in divorce, well, discovery.
And the most important result from this from our perspective, was that.
Within each conference.
The.
Guided role discovery.
Did a lot better than the unguarded rule discovery.
So that led us to believe that, at least for this task.
That the role definitions used using guidance.
We have higher quality than the unguarded rule definitions.
And there were some other interesting results that the data mining.
If you look at the data mining conferences.
They generally did a better job of matching than some of these other conferences that are maybe a little bit different than.
KDD, such as SIGMOD and VLDB.
And that makes sense because you might not expect people in in different types of conferences to be playing the same roles, because there are different communities to some extent.
So the other thing we wanted to try to figure out was whether or not.
Looking at alternative rule discovery made sense and one of the questions was could we even find multiple sets of?
Roles in the same graph that were both useful and that were different from each other.
So again, we use the KDD coauthor graph for this experiment.
We performed well discovery on it, and we performed alternate role discovery and.
We analyzed both sets of rolls that were produced.
And.
In this slide, I'll show you some of the results from that.
In the electronic version of the paper, you can actually.
This is a KDD coauthor graph.
You can actually zoom in on this map and see the different authors.
That these nodes represent so you can see their names.
But all of the colored nodes in this graph represent authors who originally in one role.
In the original discovery result.
And the color that they have represents what role they were mapped to in the alternate role discovery result.
So we looked at what this role originally meant.
We looked at who who belonged to this role.
The people who are colored.
And they were all highly influential people within the KDD community.
And then we we looked at the red and the blue rolls.
Because most of the people were mapped to red or blue.
And.
We looked at what what those roles meant, and it turns out the red rolls are globally influential.
People.
There are people that were not only influential, but were influential.
Across different areas of data mining and the blue people were locally influential people.
They were highly influential, but maybe.
Constrained within a certain area.
So this is an important result for us because.
It showed that yes, you can find multiple definitions of rules within same graph and in our formulations capable of discovering it.
So in conclusion, we showed how guidance can be encoded in the non negative matrix factorization of roll discovery.
We showed empirically that adding guidance can improve the quality of role definitions.
And we showed that alternative roles do exist in graphs and our formulation can find it.
In the future, we want to look at additional types of guidance that can be added.
And possibly more complex settings where different types of guns might be needed.
